student.name: Ben Massfeller
student.project: Does Adding Weight to a Car Change Its Speed?
student.hypothesis: I predict that adding weight to a Hot Wheels car will make it go faster because gravity pulls heavier objects with more force down the ramp.

experiment.dv: Speed (m/s) and time (seconds) measured by IR break-beam sensors
experiment.cv: Track (6.01m), start height, release method (gravity only — no push), car model per condition, NFC tag mass (0.025g)

equipment.system: M.A.S.S. Trap v2.6.0-beta — Motion Analysis & Speed System
equipment.sensors: Dual IR break-beam sensors (start gate + finish gate) with microsecond timing
equipment.track: Hot Wheels track, 6.01 meters, gravity-powered (no motors or launchers)

timeline.title: System Assembly & First Boot
timeline.description: Assembled the M.A.S.S. Trap finish gate and start gate. Connected IR sensors, wired ESP32-S3 boards, and confirmed communication between devices over ESP-NOW mesh network. First successful race timed at the kitchen table.

timeline.title: NFC Evidence Tags & Weighing Protocol
timeline.description: Weighed all test vehicles on a milligram scale. Discovered that two 'identical' F-150 trucks differ by 6.479g (20.5% variance!). Applied NTAG213 NFC stickers (0.025g each) to every car for automatic identification. Created the evidence tag system with QR codes and case numbers.
timeline.discovery: Two identical Hot Wheels F-150 trucks weigh 38.000g and 31.521g — a 20.5% difference. Manufacturing variance is a real variable!

timeline.title: Experiment Design & Variable Definition
timeline.description: Defined the independent variable (added weight), dependent variable (speed and time), and controlled variables (track length, height, release method). Selected 'Mass vs Speed' experiment template. Chose tungsten weights for precise mass additions.

timeline.title: 6-Phase Lab Manager & Dry Run Testing
timeline.description: Tested the full 6-phase forensic lab workflow in dry-run mode. Walked through experiment setup, vehicle intake, evidence prep (case number assignment), pre-flight check, and confirmed the data collection flow. Identified UX improvements needed and fixed them in real-time.
learnings: Dry-run mode uses DRY26- prefix so real case numbers aren't consumed
Need to photograph cars on scale BEFORE testing begins (chain of custody)
The system auto-advances between runs — just follow the screen instructions

methodology.title: Forensic Evidence Chain Protocol
steps: Each test run is assigned a unique case number (MASS26-XXXX) BEFORE data collection begins
Every vehicle is weighed to milligram precision and photographed on the scale
Evidence tags with QR codes are printed for each test condition
Photos are captured BEFORE testing (chain of custody — document before you touch)
The system randomizes run order using Locard's Exchange Principle to prevent systematic bias
Each condition is tested 3 times (trials) to verify reproducibility
Sanity checks flag suspicious readings (too fast, too slow, or identical) for review
All data is exported in metric units (seconds, m/s, grams) as required by the rubric

tech_details.timing_precision: Microsecond (1/1,000,000 second) resolution using hardware interrupts
tech_details.clock_sync: Start and finish gates synchronize clocks every 5 seconds over ESP-NOW radio
tech_details.data_integrity: Dual persistence — data saved on phone AND on the ESP32 device after every run
